title: What the Senate Filibuster Assault Means
summary: Wednesday's narrow vote changed Senate races, starting in 2022.. Washington wisdom once held that while Sens. Joe Manchin and Kyrsten Sinema were the public faces of Democratic reluctance to breaking the Senate filibuster, others in the caucus quietly supported the duo. But on Wednesday night, 48 out of 50 Senate Democrats voted to use the "nuclear option" in an attempt to overturn election laws in most states.

title: Biden's Pointless Vaccine Mandate
summary: After another defeat in court, it's time to end this unpopular coercion.. The Biden Administration said Friday it will appeal a federal judge's injunction against its vaccine mandate for federal employees. But why bother? The White House says 98% of federal workers have complied. Increasingly the Biden mandates seem more about punishing than protecting people.

title: America's Ever-Expanding Criminal Code
summary: The number of federal crimes has increased 36% since the 1990s.. How many federal crimes has Congress created? The question seems like it ought to have a straightforward answer that citizens can look up. In fact it's more like asking, "how many genes are in the human genome?" The answer is in the many thousands, but despite decades of counting, no one knows for sure.

title: The Supreme Court's McGirt Cleanup
summary: Native American victims deserve to have crimes against them prosecuted.. The Supreme Court made a mess in Oklahoma two years ago, but the good news is the Justices might now be moving to help clean it up. On Friday they agreed to hear an appeal that could refill some of the prosecutorial vacuum left by McGirt, the High Court's gravely misguided 2020 ruling.

title: Pete Davidson and Colin Jost Buy a Staten Island Ferry
summary: The "Saturday Night Live" cast members plan to turn decommissioned ferryboat into entertainment venue. Before they were famous, Staten Island natives Pete Davidson and Colin Jost grew up riding the Staten Island Ferry.

title: Eternity and the Grateful Dead
summary: A video of their 1981 concert in Essen, Germany, sent me thinking about the life after this one.. One morning under an ominous sky, my friend Michael texted me a video of the Grateful Dead performing "Looks Like Rain." He was right as, well, rain. Shortly afterward, the heavens opened and a deluge fell.

title: Google's 'Inclusive Language' Police
summary: The company labels terms like 'senior citizen,' 'dummy variable,' and 'black box' verboten.. The physicist Richard Feynman once told a story about his father taking him out in the woods to observe nature. Feynman saw a bird and asked what it was called. His father said the name was irrelevant-it was only important to see how a bird behaved if you wanted to learn about it. I have a hard time remembering names, which is one of the reasons I became a physicist and not a physician, as my mother wanted.

title: AT&T and the Netflix Streaming Crack-Up
summary: Ma Bell is missing the boat on bundling as it insists on unwinding the Warner Media deal.. Still liking AT&T 's plan to spin off its giant Warner Media acquisition especially in view of Netflix 's big selloff Friday? The press was over the moon about the pending dismemberment when it was announced eight months ago. It involved big dollars and a big climb-down by Ma Bell's management, which had recently fought the Justice Department to put the two together.

title: How Minnesota Went From Tom Sawyer to Huck Finn
summary: Fifty years ago it was 'the state that works.' Now it's become a microcosm of an America in crisis.. I wrote an August 1973 cover story for Time magazine that praised Minnesota as "the state that works." The cover photograph showed Gov. Wendell Anderson, dressed in a plaid flannel shirt, grinning and holding up a northern pike that he had just caught in one of Minnesota's 12,000 lakes.

title: Democrats Start to Sketch Out Revived Build Back Better Package
summary: Priorities in new round of talks include reducing carbon emissions, expanding child care and lowering healthcare costs. WASHINGTON-Democrats began to revive their efforts to pass a major child-care, healthcare and climate package as lawmakers started to accept that they would have to further cater to Sen. Joe Manchin (D., W.Va.) in hopes of reaching a deal on a scaled-back plan.

title: U.S. Suspends 44 Flights to China Operated by Chinese Airlines
summary: Biden administration move comes after Chinese authorities canceled some flights from the U.S. and other countries, citing Covid-19 containment rules. The Biden administration Friday suspended dozens of flights operated by Chinese airlines, in response to similar measures taken by China's aviation authorities in recent weeks.

title: Google Seeks Dismissal of Ad Practices Suit
summary: Resume Subscription. Alphabet Inc.'s Google asked a federal judge Friday to dismiss an antitrust lawsuit brought by Texas and more than a dozen state attorneys general, arguing that they failed to show the search giant's digital advertising practices were anticompetitive.

title: U.S. Makes Visa Changes to Retain Foreign STEM Students
summary: Moves are designed to boost innovation in the U.S. while keeping pace with competitors such as China. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration is making a series of policy changes aimed at easing the path for foreign students and professionals in the fields of science, technology, engineering and math to remain in the U.S. on a long-term basis.

title: Mexico's TV Azteca Faces Creditor Ultimatum After Skipping Interest Payments
summary: Some lenders to the multimedia company say they plan to take action to seize the broadcaster's assets if the company doesn't agree to a repayment plan. A consortium of U.S.-based creditors to Mexican multimedia conglomerate TV Azteca S.A.B. de C.V. has threatened to take action to seize its assets in Mexico and abroad after the company skipped a year's worth of interest payments and is on the cusp of forgoing another in February, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Brian Laundrie Claimed Responsibility for Gabby Petito's Murder, FBI Says
summary: Agency ends its investigation into killing that garnered national attention, citing notebook found near man's body. Brian Laundrie claimed responsibility for killing his fiancée, Gabby Petito, in a notebook that was found near his body, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Nasdaq, S&P Finish Worst Week Since March 2020
summary: Oil, cryptocurrencies drop; investors register disappointing reports from Netflix and Peloton. All three major U.S. indexes fell for a third consecutive week, continuing their slide to start 2022, with investors worried about the prospect of higher interest rates and their effect on valuations.

title: How Robinhood Investors Robbed Themselves
summary: Herding into the same stocks made novice investors feel like geniuses, but the party is over and it was predictable. Following the crowd works-until it doesn't. A new generation of traders getting their tips from social media and using apps like Robinhood to choose stocks are learning that the hard way.

title: Intel to Invest $20 Billion in U.S. Chip-Making Facility
summary: Company will make cutting-edge processors at new site near Columbus, creating around 3,000 permanent jobs. Intel Corp. said it plans to invest at least $20 billion in new chip-making capacity in Ohio, bolstering the company's semiconductor-production ambitions as greater demand for digital products and a global chip shortage have amplified the need for more manufacturing.

title: U.S., Russia Agree to Keep Negotiating to Defuse Ukraine Crisis
summary: Washington to provide response to the Kremlin's demands to cease what Moscow sees as threats to its security from NATO, Western powers. Washington and Moscow on Friday agreed to continue talks triggered by Russia's military buildup near the Ukrainian border, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken saying the U.S. would formally address the Kremlin's concerns that Western powers threaten Russian security and its demands regarding the future of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: The Once and Future Drug War
summary: During the 50 years the U.S. has battled the narcotics trade, illegal drugs have become more available and potent. But that's no reason to give up. Governments must adapt and find answers beyond law enforcement. America's longest war isn't the 20-year fight in Afghanistan. That struggle is dwarfed by the War on Drugs, started by President Richard Nixon more than 50 years ago and still raging.

title: Netflix Plunge Deepens Nasdaq's Correction
summary: Streaming giant's shares fall 22%. Plunging shares of Netflix Inc . and other streamers dragged the Nasdaq Composite Index deeper into correction territory Friday, as a selloff in government bonds and lackluster earnings have eroded demand for the once-highflying tech trade.

title: Morgan Stanley's Gorman Gets $35 Million for 2021
summary: Bank notched record results last year; pay beat that of JPMorgan's Jamie Dimon. Morgan Stanley paid Chief Executive Officer James Gorman $35 million for his work in 2021, a 6% raise from the previous year and his largest pay package ever since becoming CEO in 2010.

title: IBM Sells Watson Health Assets to Investment Firm
summary: The deal continues IBM's efforts to refocus core business around the cloud. International Business Machines Corp. agreed to sell the data and analytics assets from its Watson Health business to investment firm Francisco Partners, the companies said Friday.

title: Former Giuliani Associate Sentenced to One Year and a Day in Prison
summary: The Florida businessman pleaded guilty to soliciting a political donation from a foreign national. A former associate of Rudy Giuliani was sentenced by a federal judge Friday to a year and a day in prison on a campaign-finance charge, capping the fall of a key figure in the first impeachment inquiry into former President Donald Trump.

title: A New Biden Answer for Unfulfilled Promises
summary: After a disappointing press conference, the president tries out a new explanation in a message to Democrats.. Deciphering the true meaning of a Joe Biden comment is never easy. But in a Thursday video conference with Democrats, the president appeared to be road-testing a new explanation for his unfulfilled promises: They weren't really promises!

title: Rows Garden (Variety Puzzle, January 22)
Field of Dreams (Saturday Crossword, January 22)
Antiabortion Supporters Rally in D.C. as Court Weighs Overruling Roe
summary: Marchers say they hope for 'a monumental decision' as court considers case to overturn protections for women's abortion rights. WASHINGTON-Antiabortion supporters rallied in the nation's capital on Friday saying they were hopeful that the Supreme Court was on the cusp of overruling the landmark 1973 Roe v. Wade decision that made abortion legal nationwide.

title: New York Rangers Player Jacob Trouba Buys Manhattan Condo
summary: The hockey player paid $6.7 million for a unit at celebrity-friendly 443 Greenwich in Tribeca. Professional hockey player Jacob Trouba has bought a Manhattan condo for $6.7 million, according to public records.

title: Your Raise Might Be Stock Investors' Pay Cut
summary: Inflation and wage pressures are about to rain on investors' parade. Corporate profits boomed last year, but U.S. companies might have a hard time generating much of an encore.

title: Judge Blocks Biden Covid-19 Vaccine Mandate for Federal Workers
summary: President lacked authority to mandate shots, ruling says. A federal judge blocked the Biden administration's Covid-19 vaccine requirement for federal employees, the latest legal setback for the president's push to inoculate workers.

title: Germany Bars NATO Ally From Transferring Weapons to Ukraine
summary: Refusal to permit Estonia to transfer artillery that originated in Germany points to strains in Western alliance over Ukraine. Germany is blocking North Atlantic Treaty Organization ally Estonia from giving military support to Ukraine by refusing to issue permits for German-origin weapons to be exported to Kyiv as it braces for a potential Russian invasion.

title: How the U.S. Messed Up Its New 5G Rollout: 'It Wasn't Our Finest Hour'
summary: Resume Subscription. The Biden and Trump administrations had years of warnings. But the government failed this week to avoid a collision between U.S. telecom companies and airlines over the rollout of new 5G cellular networks.

title: The Underside of the 'Great Resignation'
summary: The trend toward idleness has been years in the making, says the author of 'Men Without Work.' That's an ill omen for the economy and the culture.. It's been months now, but hiring managers everywhere are still waiting by their phones. They've been told not to worry-the job applicants are coming. Absent workers are just taking some time, right? You know, checking out their options . . .

title: China's Economic Downturn Gives Rise to a Winter of Discontent
summary: With Xi likely seeking a third term, his critics may have more leverage than they have had for years.. China's economic future isn't looking all that bright and is starting to have political implications for President Xi Jinping. The Chinese Academy of Social Sciences expects annual growth to slow to 5.3% in 2022 from 8% in 2021. Real-estate giant Evergrande, declared in default last month by ratings agencies, unleashed a wave of defaults in the country's property sector, which is worth about 29% of gross domestic product.

title: How to Order Free Rapid Covid-19 Tests From the Government
summary: Americans can place orders for free Covid-19 tests via a new site. What you need to know.. Americans can now order free at-home rapid Covid-19 tests through a new government website.

title: Swedbank Names New Chief Compliance Officer
summary: The Swedish lender has hired Britta Hjorth-Larsen, who currently serves as head of nonfinancial risk at Bank of Ireland. Swedbank AB has hired Britta Hjorth-Larsen as its new chief compliance officer, ending a four-month search.

title: Companies Face Patchwork of Covid-19 Rules After Supreme Court Ruling
summary: Companies will have to fend for themselves-and grapple with varied state and local requirements-following the high court's decision to overturn the Biden administration's mandate for large employers. Business leaders who were scrambling to survey employees on their vaccination status and line up scarce testing resources breathed a sigh of relief after the Supreme Court overturned the Biden administration's vaccine-or-test mandate for large private employers.

title: Airbus Cancels Qatar Airways Plane Contract, a Rare Move Amid Growing Spat
summary: Cancellation is the latest move in a monthslong fight. LONDON- Airbus SE scrapped a $6 billion jet contract with Qatar Airways Ltd., part of an escalating legal battle between the two over paint.

title: Texas Man Charged With Threatening to Kill Georgia Officials Over 2020 Election
summary: Case is first to be issued by Justice Department task force set up last year to prosecute alleged threats against elections officials. WASHINGTON-Federal prosecutors have charged a Texas man with threatening to kill Georgia government officials, in the first case brought by a Justice Department task force created to combat crimes against election workers.

title: China Says Local Officials Underreported Deaths in Flooding
summary: Beijing says officials in Henan province intentionally concealed or delayed reporting of casualties after July floods. Chinese officials intentionally underreported the number of people who died or went missing in severe flooding in Henan province in July, China's central government said, a rare acknowledgment of officials concealing the true death toll in a disaster.

title: 19 Books We Read This Week
summary: Amartya Sen's journey, a good deed that leads to a sinister mystery, Carlyle's revolution, the mistake that changed World War II and more..

title: Yellen Views Biden Policies as Modernized Supply-Side Economics
summary: In speech to World Economic Forum, Treasury secretary says White House is aiming to increase labor supply and boost worker productivity. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the Biden administration is aiming to boost U.S. economic capacity by focusing on issues like labor supply and public infrastructure, an approach she called "modern supply-side economics."

title: Beatrix Potter's Eye for Nature
summary: Before creating Peter Rabbit, the British writer and artist made scientific illustrations of fungi and beetles. Britain's brief but fertile Edwardian period was a golden age of children's literature. The first decade of the 20th century saw the stage premiere of J.M. Barrie's "Peter Pan" and the publication of Kenneth Grahame's "The Wind in the Willows." But no writer represents the genre in its heyday better than Beatrix Potter, whose diminutive illustrated picture books gave the world Peter Rabbit, Tomasina Tittlemouse and a host of other precocious animal characters. Precise, expressive watercolor illustrations by the author were the trademark of her books, which have now sold hundreds of millions of copies.

title: Louie Anderson, Comedian and 'Baskets' Star, Dies at 68
summary: Emmy-award winner whose career spanned four decades died from complications from cancer. Louie Anderson, the Emmy-award winning actor and comedian, died Friday in Las Vegas. He was 68 years old.

title: Democrats Push to Revive $250 Billion Tech Investment Bill to Counter China
summary: Bill passed by Senate-including $52 billion to boost chip production-has stalled in the House. WASHINGTON-A $250 billion spending initiative to boost U.S. investment in high-tech research and manufacturing has stalled in the House, despite lawmakers' increasing concerns over global competitiveness.

title: John Mellencamp Wants to Make Great Albums, Not Hit Songs
summary: At 70, the singer-songwriter is creating music without compromise. John Mellencamp doesn't much care what you think about him. "I just don't give a f-," he says. "I never did look for acceptance-from my parents, from my teachers, from my record company." He single-mindedly pursues whatever he thinks is right: "You do not want to argue with me," he says.

title: Islamic State Kills Sleeping Iraqi Soldiers, Attacks Syrian Prison
summary: Violence shows continued threat of extremist group despite its territorial defeat in the region. Islamic State militants killed 11 Iraqi soldiers sleeping in their camp while dozens died after its fighters launched a prison break attempt in Syria, indicating how the extremist group remains a potent threat despite its territorial defeat in the region.

title: Microsoft's Activision Blizzard Deal Poses Sustainability Challenge
summary: Software giant would have to address workplace problems at videogame maker and big gap between the companies' ESG disclosures and policies. Microsoft Corp. could have its work cut out getting Activision Blizzard Inc.'s sustainability programs up to its own standards if its planned $75 billion acquisition of the videogame maker goes ahead.

title: Knit Pants: Like Sweats, but Chic
summary: As we straddle WFH and re-entering society, stretchy but un-slovenly knit, kick-flare pants can bridge the divide between being comfortable and presentable. Here, five cropped pairs that will take you from the living room to the dinner party.. "I'M VERY comfortable," said Ashley Sanchez, 31, on a recent Zoom call. Ms. Sanchez, the San Francisco-based styling-team lead at Stitch Fix , a company that creates outfits for customers using a combination of algorithms and stylists, was only visible from the ribcage up; her tailored blazer and layered necklaces didn't look particularly relaxed. But she confided that, below screen level, she had on a pair of stretchy, crop-flare knit pants.

title: The Great Hamster Rescue Sends Hong Kong Into a Furry Frenzy
summary: Resume Subscription. HONG KONG-Ken Chow, a 37-year-old jobs broker, already had four hamsters in his 150-square-foot apartment when the government announced it was embarking on a massive cull of the tiny pets in an effort to curb a Covid-19 outbreak.

title: Beijing Olympics' Strict Covid Rules Loom for Recently Infected Athletes
summary: A lower threshold for positive tests could mean athletes who recently tested negative will test positive in China. As Team USA athletes head into the final 14 days before the Beijing Winter Olympics, some face an uncertain entry into the strictest bubble ever created for a world sporting event.

title: Readers Reply to WSJ Publisher Almar Latour
summary: 'I expect the Journal not to waver or bend to the dogmas du jour. I hold you to your word every morning.'. On the morning of Jan. 15, as usual, I picked up the Journal from the driveway, poured a cup of coffee and started reading the paper cover to cover. Almar Latour's publisher's letter ("A Report to Our Readers") was an unexpected synthesis of the Journal's activities and principles in lieu of the readers' letters. I have been a loyal subscriber for more years than I care to remember, and Mr. Latour nicely summarizes why. The Journal costs more than three of my streaming services taken together, but its value well exceeds theirs.

title: After His Georgia Speech, Can Biden Turn Back?
summary: Readers respond to Peggy Noonan's column on the president's 'break point.'. Peggy Noonan's column "Biden's Georgia Speech Is a Break Point," (Declarations, Jan. 15) hit the nail on the head. Since President Biden's over-the-top rant grouping his opponents with white supremacists, I have rarely read so many condemnations from such a wide spectrum of writers.

title: 'Bambi,' Whittaker Chambers and the Art of Translation
summary: A grandson defends the ex-spy's less-famous literary work.. Meghan Cox Gurdon's review of Jack Zipes's new translation of "Bambi: A Life in the Woods" (Books, Jan. 15) does an injustice to my grandfather, Whittaker Chambers, and his 1928 translation of the novel.

title: Is Dissent on Covid Policy Deadly?
summary: Discussion has been heavy on politics and light on science.. An internet search of Joseph Ladapo will yield commentary labeling him as anti-science, unfit for his duties and even deadly ("Florida Is Living With Covid-and Freedom" by James Taranto, Weekend Interview, Jan. 15). What it does not yield is a well-constructed explanation as to what makes him these things. Our country's response to Covid has been heavy on political messaging and light on scientific discussion. It has been nice to see Dr. Ladapo rise above that and recognize a need to fight Covid without forgetting about his community's other health needs.

title: Why Socialist Indoctrination Ultimately Fails
summary: A case for optimism, in a way.. I am more optimistic than Prof. John Ellis ("Can Politics Get Better When Higher Ed Keeps Getting Worse?" op-ed, Jan. 15). Seventy years of Communist education in the Soviet Union, backed by the power of a totalitarian state, ultimately failed. Similarly, left-wing indoctrination in U.S. universities will not succeed. The reason is that socialism and left-wing policies inevitably fail-something so obvious that only academics are incapable of perceiving it.

title: 'Home in the World' Review: Nobel Laureate Amartya Sen Speaks
summary: A memoir of the economist's journey from Calcutta to Cambridge, and onto the world stage as an advocate for the downtrodden.. When Amartya Sen-then not quite 20 years of age-arrived at Cambridge University from India in 1953, the landlady at the "digs" assigned to him by his college wasn't entirely delighted to see him. She was, writes Mr. Sen in "Home in the World," worried "about having me in the house since she had never met a non-white person before (though, she added, she had seen them in trains and buses)."

title: 'The French Revolution' Review: Thomas Carlyle's Masterpiece, Complete
summary: A fresh confrontation with the fiery author's sprawling, influential work.. 'It all stands pretty fair in my head, nor do I mean to investigate much more about it, but to splash down what I know, in large masses of colours; that it may look like a smoke-and-flame conflagration in the distance,-which it is." So wrote Thomas Carlyle to his wife, Jane, before beginning the last volume of his history of the French Revolution. The work took Carlyle three years to write, and its publication in 1837 made the Scotsman one of the foremost writers in Britain. Over the next decade he would achieve fame across Europe and America as a historian, literary critic and political essayist-as, to use an anachronistic term, an intellectual.

title: Trump's Ego Got in the Way of His Success
summary: The result was President Biden.. The editorial "Biden's Operation Snail Speed" (Jan. 13) and subsequent letters ("Where Are the Covid Therapies, Mr. President?" Jan. 20) only aggravate my disgust with President Trump. It is maddening that a man's acute egocentrism can blind an electorate to the success of his presidency and give us President Biden.

title: Mysteries: Antoine Wilson's 'Mouth to Mouth'
summary: A lifesaving act of resuscitation leads to unexpected questions about money, art and morality in this psychological thriller.. The unnamed narrator of Antoine Wilson's "Mouth to Mouth" is a struggling writer who learns much more than he expects from Jeff Cook, an old college acquaintance he encounters, after 20 years, at New York's JFK Airport. Like the Ancient Mariner in the Coleridge poem, Cook is in a confessional mood. Fueled by alcohol in the airport lounge, waiting for an international connection, he launches into a long story which begins: "Not long after college . . . I was, through no planning or forethought on my part, responsible for saving a man's life."

title: Quick and Healthy Seafood Recipe: A Fresh, Delicious Ceviche
summary: Ready in 15 minutes, this dish of shrimp and firm white fish brightened with mango and chiles 'cooks' in a marinade of lime juice, olive oil and salt. Scoop it up with a crisp corn tostada or tortilla chips.. AN EXPERIENCED CHEF and entrepreneur in her native Mexico before moving to the U.S., Cristina Martinez has gained a devoted following, locally and nationally, with her Philadelphia restaurants South Philly Barbacoa, Casa México and the People's Kitchen. The Netflix series "Chef's Table" brought her to an even wider audience. "This is always who she's been," said her husband and business partner, Benjamin Miller. "She's a boss."

title: The Huge Tax Bills That Came Out of Nowhere at Vanguard
summary: A change that benefited big clients left little ones holding the bag. It's easy for a small investor to make big mistakes. It would be even easier for giant investment firms to help prevent them-but, sadly, the asset-management industry seems to have other priorities.

title: 'Hitler's American Gamble' Review: The Mistake That Changed World War II
summary: Nazi misconceptions about the U.S. drove a nightmarish strategy that would doom millions.. Most Americans, if asked, would probably say that Franklin Roosevelt declared war on Nazi Germany, following the bombing of Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941. Since we were at war with imperial Japan, the logic would run, we were obliged to be at war with Japan's Axis ally.

title: Washington Nationals Part Owners List Home With Locker Room-Style Bathroom
summary: Mike Tyson and other pro athletes have been guests at the home outside Washington, D.C..

title: 'Seven Games' Review: Chess Knights, Poker Cowboys and the Rise of the Computer Opponent
summary: Acolytes of tabletop strategy dedicate lifetimes to the mysteries of the board and the card deck. Will A.I. send them all back to hopscotch?. In Washington Square Park, they don't agree to draws. The first time I sat down at a black marble table to play one of Manhattan's celebrated chess hustlers, I weathered the attack and simplified into a theoretically drawn endgame, at which point both players would usually shake hands. But the time left on my clock was low, and there was $5 riding on the result, so the guy made me prove it: We played until only bare kings remained on the board. Chess might be an art for some, a science for others; most of all, though, it is a fight.

title: Children's Books: A Bookshelf Crowded With Progressive Piety
summary: Illustrated lives of contemporary figures are increasingly numerous, and increasingly ideological.. Name any hero or heroine of contemporary culture and you can be assured that the person stars in an illustrated biography for children. The band of favorites includes but is not limited to: Gloria Steinem, Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama, Rosa Parks, Muhammad Ali, Harvey Milk, Anthony Fauci, Greta Thunberg, Oprah Winfrey, Sonia Sotomayor and Ruth Bader Ginsburg. The last two constitute a cottage industry in themselves, such is the gush of books about them.

title: 'The Church of Saint Thomas Paine' Review: Prophets of American Secular Religion
summary: Feeling out of place in Protestant churches, secularists sought a 'religion of duty, religion of character, and religion of daily life.'. The challenge of memorializing the life of the deceased without resorting to religion was a problem that confounded H.L. Mencken, often remembered as 1920s America's village atheist (though he professed agnosticism). After observing the parting ceremonies for two "admittedly damned" friends (read unbelievers), Mencken envied people of faith for having better parting ceremonies. At the gathering of one of his former friends, no one was allowed to speak. So "six of us walked into his house in utter silence" and later stood by as the remains were "shoved, in the same crawling silence, into the fire-box of the crematory." The other friend was an anti-clerical socialist whose wife had asked two comrades to say a few words. They had prepared by "resorting to the jug," which rendered them garrulous but also "injudicious." Both instances, Mencken observed, violated an ancient human sentiment by dispatching such charming fellows "in so cavalier a fashion."

title: Fiction: 'The Hummingbird' by Sandro Veronesi
summary: The award-winning author of 'Quiet Chaos' offers another story of heartbreak and endurance.. Sandro Veronesi won Italy's major book award, the Strega Prize, in 2006 for his powerful novel "Quiet Chaos," about the existential grappling of a newly widowed father, and he won again in 2020 for "The Hummingbird," which now appears in English courtesy of translator Elena Pala. Mr. Veronesi is clearly on to something, as far as the prize's jurors are concerned. "The Hummingbird" again depicts the philosophical education of a man enduring the blows of heartbreak and devastating loss. The protagonist is a Florentine named Marco Carrera. Marco is an ophthalmologist and, as dictated by the laws of literature, his tragedy is that he can't see what's coming at him.

title: Airstrikes in Yemen Kill At Least 70 People as Saudi-Led Coalition Ramps Up Offensive
summary: The attack comes days after the Iran-allied Houthi rebels claimed a deadly aerial strike on the U.A.E.. A Saudi-led coalition airstrike on Friday on Houthi-controlled territory in Yemen hit a prison, the rebel group said, killing dozens and injuring scores of others.

title: 'Seasons of Purgatory' Review: An Iranian Writer's Art in Exile
summary: Shahriar Mandanipour's stories unveil beauty and horror in the nation he left behind.. Sometimes we never see the wrongs that blight our lives. Or else we glimpse them once-before the end. In Shahriar Mandanipour's story "Mummy and Honey," a viper slips into a house in mourning. It takes up residence, at first "gently coiled around the bitter orange tree." Grandfather, ruler of the family, has passed. Now Father and his warring sons squabble over the old man's legacy as the elusive serpent flickers at the corner of vision like "a stream of molten gold." When this scaly symbol of "spellbinding doom" comes into view, everything will change.

title: Five Best: Books on the Mitford Sisters
summary: Selected by Rachel Johnson, the author, most recently, of 'Rake's Progress: The Madcap True Tale of My Political Midlife Crisis.'. By Harold Acton (1975)

title: Wall Street Titans Support One of Their Own, David McCormick, for Senate
summary: Stephen Schwarzman and Ken Griffin are among those hosting a March fundraiser for the former Bridgewater CEO. David McCormick, the former chief executive of hedge fund giant Bridgewater Associates who is running for the open Senate seat in Pennsylvania, has the backing of some of Wall Street's biggest names.

title: Justice Sonia Sotomayor Encourages Children to Help Others in New Kids' Book
summary: Supreme Court justice's new book, "Just Help! How to Build a Better World," comes out on Jan. 25. Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor's new children's book, called "Just Help! How to Build a Better World," will be released early next week, telling the story of a neighborhood where people help each other.

title: Chile's Incoming Leftist President Moves to Calms Markets
summary: President-elect Gabriel Boric says the head of the central bank will run economic policy in Latin America's most affluent nation. Chile's President-elect Gabriel Boric said he would appoint central bank chief Mario Marcel as finance minister, seeking to ease concerns among investors worried the incoming administration will move the country far to the left.

title: Bitcoin, Netflix, Peloton, Coinbase: What to Watch in the Stock Market Today
summary: Netflix warned of slower subscriber growth; Cryptocurrencies were broadly down. Wall Street stock indexes opened lower after disappointing earnings reports from some popular technology stocks. Here's what we're watching at the end of a rough week on Wall Street:

title: 'Revanchist': Seeking Revenge-And Not Just Over Territory
summary: The term for a country that stakes a claim beyond its borders comes from the same root as 'vindicate' and 'vendetta'. Linguist and lexicographer Ben Zimmer analyzes the origins of words in the news. Read previous columns here.

title: Singer Meat Loaf of 'Bat Out of Hell' Dies at 74
summary: Singer's six-decade career included one of the bestselling albums of all time and dozens of movie appearances as an actor. American singer Meat Loaf, whose 1977 album "Bat Out of Hell" is one of the bestselling of all time, has died at 74, his family said in a statement.

title: Naomi Osaka Eliminated From Australian Open by U.S. Hopeful Amanda Anisimova
summary: The 20-year-old knocked out the defending champion in three sets to set up a clash with world No. 1 Ashleigh Barty. Naomi Osaka landed in Melbourne this month fully prepared to move on from the most turbulent year of her career and defend her Australian Open title. Returning from the mental-health break she took from tennis at the end of last year, she hit the ball cleaner, moved more freely and seemed ready to work back toward her place as one of the most dominant hard court players in tennis.

title: More Starbucks Baristas Seek to Unionize
summary: Number of stores considering unionization remains a small fraction of coffee chain's overall total. A unionization push among Starbucks Corp. workers is spreading across the U.S., challenging executives' efforts to curb labor organization within the nation's biggest coffee chain.

title: France's Total Exits Myanmar, Citing Shareholder Pressure Since Coup
summary: Western energy companies face growing calls to divest or withhold revenue from junta as human-rights situation worsens. SINGAPORE-France's TotalEnergies SE said it is withdrawing from Myanmar over shareholder pressure and a deteriorating human-rights situation since the country's military seized power in a coup last year.

title: A Covid Contact-Tracing Contrast Lays Bare China's Inequalities
summary: Itineraries produce starkly different pictures of life in Beijing; migrant worker's tale sparks outpouring of sympathy. HONG KONG-Two Covid-19 contact-tracing efforts in China's capital have combined to open a window into extreme inequality that has engrossed many in the world's most populous country.

title: 'Farms Are Failing' as Fertilizer Prices Drive Up Cost of Food
summary: Resume Subscription. From South America's avocado, corn and coffee farms to Southeast Asia's plantations of coconuts and oil palms, high fertilizer prices are weighing on farmers across the developing world, making it much costlier to cultivate and forcing many to cut back on production.

title: Luxury Learning Vacations 2022: From the Maldives to the North Pole
summary: On a trip to the new Ritz-Carlton Maldives resort, a traveler combines her pampering R&R with hands-on lessons on marine ecology. Plus: Four other upscale retreats where guests can join scientists in the field.. THE FIRST TIME I took a biology class, I sat inside a drab, windowless lab room in my Phoenix high school. The last time, this past November, I was on a boat in the Indian Ocean as conservation biologist Sol Milne tried to convince me not to worry about swimming beside sharks.

title: The 'Ozark' Guide to How Not to Parent Your Kids
summary: Resume Subscription. Marty and Wendy Byrde are money launderers juggling relationships with a heroin manufacturer, a cartel boss and the FBI. But the "Ozark" couple's thorniest challenge? Parenting the two kids they turned into accomplices.

title: Blackstone, Starwood Team Up to Buy Longer-Stay Hotels for $1.5 Billion
summary: Real-estate investors strike $1.5 billion deal for 111 properties under WoodSpring Suites brand; seller is Brookfield. Real-estate investors Blackstone Inc. and Starwood Capital Group are teaming up for the second time in less than a year in a big bet on the extended-stay hotel sector.

title: GlaxoSmithKline Racing to Provide Only Effective Covid-19 Antibody Treatment
summary: GlaxoSmithKline and Vir Biotechnology are increasing output at a second plant to help meet demand for sotrovimab. GlaxoSmithKline PLC and partner Vir Biotechnology Inc. are straining to meet soaring demand for their Covid-19 antibody treatment after the highly mutated Omicron variant knocked out the two competing products.

title: The Rams Hunt for Value. They Found Cooper Kupp.
summary: The former third-round pick became the NFL's best receiver in 2021. He also explains why a team that gives away its top selections has a chance at the Super Bowl.. The 2017 NFL draft marked the beginning of an unorthodox experiment unlike anything the league had seen in decades. It was the first of seven straight years when the Rams traded away their first-round pick, owing to a series of blockbuster deals that most recently has helped them acquire stars in quarterback Matthew Stafford and cornerback Jalen Ramsey.

title: EV Makers' Next Headache: Scarce Battery Chemicals, Made in China
summary: Lithium used to make electric-vehicle batteries is getting dear; that is only leading edge of supply-chain problem. Last year was the year of electric vehicles-global sales are likely to have hit a record, in turn pushing up battery demand. Now too much of a good thing is causing problems: Many key battery materials, including but not limited to processed lithium itself, are in short supply and prices are rising sharply.

title: How Afghan Refugees Are Vetted, Where They're Going and How to Help
summary: A majority have moved into communities around the country, where agencies are helping them find homes, apply for jobs and enroll their children in school. More than 76,000 Afghans have been brought to the U.S. since last summer, when they were airlifted from the Kabul airport during the chaotic final weeks of the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan.

title: Blackstone Launches Clean-Energy Credit Strategy
summary: Initiative is part of a plan to invest $100 billion over 10 years in businesses that help reduce carbon emissions. Blackstone Inc. has launched a credit strategy to back companies that help reduce carbon emissions, an initiative that fits into the asset manager's plan to invest $100 billion in such businesses during the next decade.

title: Carhartt Stuck With Its Covid-19 Vaccine Mandate. The Backlash Ensued.
summary: Some on social media have called for a boycott; 'we stand behind our decision,' workwear-apparel company says. One week after apparel company Carhartt Inc. declared it was keeping its Covid-19 vaccine mandate in place, the company defended its plans despite growing pushback from customers and on social media.

title: ByteDance's Revenue Growth Slowed Last Year Amid China Clampdowns
summary: Facing challenges at home, the Chinese social-media giant is banking increasingly on TikTok to drive growth abroad. Revenue at Chinese social-media giant ByteDance Ltd. rose by about 70% last year to roughly $58 billion, slowing from a year earlier, people familiar with the matter said, as Beijing tightened scrutiny over its internet sector and as an economic slowdown hit advertising sales.

title: Higher Interest Rates Won't Pay Europe's Banks Right Away
summary: Rolling back the pandemic-era support measures could offset the impact of rising rates. Rising interest rates aren't the straightforward boon to long-suffering European banks they may first appear. Patience will be required.

summary: Selections from 'My Little Golden Book about Dolly Parton' by Deborah Hopkinson, illustrated by Monique Dong. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: The Bathroom of the Future Is Here: From High-Tech Toilets to Self-Filling Tubs
summary: After two stress-filled pandemic years, some Americans are turning their bathrooms into spa-like sanctuaries complete with interactive makeup mirrors, chromotherapy showers, no-touch faucets and smart showers. THE SUGGESTION pops up on your phone in the produce section of the grocery store: "Your diet seems unbalanced. The recommended recipe is: 'Salmon/Chicken Avocado Salad.'" A message from your nutritionist? Nope. Personal trainer? If only. In this vision of the future, it's your toilet doing the talking. The Wellness Toilet concept that Toto presented at this year's Consumer Electronics Show is a commode that doubles as a health-monitoring device. The concept isn't unprecedented: Toilets capable of analyzing their contents have been on clinicians's radar for some time. But as a piece of consumer electronics, Toto's toilet is unmatched. The release date (years, not months from now) and the specific technologies are still under wraps, said Bill Strang, Toto USA's president of Corporate Strategy and eCommerce, but the trend is clear: Bathrooms have become showcases for technology on par with kitchens and home theaters.

title: Swoon in Tech Stocks Puts Startup Valuations in Harsh New Light
summary: After a blowout year, venture investors have taken note of the downturn in publicly-traded tech stocks and are beginning to question prices for late-stage funding rounds. Waning enthusiasm for tech stocks in the public markets is casting doubt on valuations in the private market, where prices last year hit stratospheric levels.

title: The English Soccer Team That Doesn't Play Soccer
summary: As postponements due to Covid-19 wreak havoc on the Premier League schedule, no club has been hit harder than Burnley, which has played the fewest matches in England. The last-place team in the English Premier League was at practice last week when the Burnley players noticed that things were a little sparse. There was more space in the locker room, fewer familiar faces running drills. Even picking teams for small-sided scrimmage was suddenly a challenge.

title: China's Yield Advantage Over U.S. Bonds Narrows
summary: Global investors are still piling into Chinese sovereign bonds. The extra yield that Chinese government bonds offer over U.S. Treasurys this week dropped below a percentage point for the first time in nearly three years, as the central banks of the world's two largest economies move in opposite directions.

title: Americans Should Pay More for Gas, Not Less
summary: There are some glaring holes in the way the U.S. regulates fuel economy and emissions. Understanding how it works (or doesn't) is key to understanding why oil demand is likely to remain high.. They are a jalopy badly in need of repairs, but America's fuel-economy rules have been rolling along since 1975, burning more oil and spewing more pollution than their builders intended. Still, when it comes to one of the few roadworthy policies available, a tuneup makes more sense than a trip to the scrap heap.

title: The SPAC Ship Is Sinking. Investors Want Their Money Back.
summary: One of the pandemic's hottest trades is cooling down, as the hype surrounding 'blank-check' companies gives way to reality. Wall Street's favorite pandemic bet is taking on water.

title: Afghans in Kosovo Risk Being Denied Entry to U.S. for Alleged Terrorist Ties
summary: About 90 Kabul evacuees are still being vetted at Camp Bondsteel. WASHINGTON-Afghan evacuees housed on a U.S. military base in Kosovo are at risk of being denied entry to the U.S. because of their alleged links to the Taliban and other terrorist groups, U.S. officials have said, potentially leaving them without a home country.

title: How Omicron Is Straining U.S. Hospitals
summary: Evidence points to less severe patient outcomes relative to previous Covid-19 variants, but the magnitude of new cases has driven up hospitalizations. The fast-spreading Omicron variant has fueled a rise in Covid-19 cases to levels far beyond any recorded in the U.S. since the start of the pandemic. But there is a growing body of evidence that infections from the Omicron variant are less severe than previous variants. So why are hospitals in some parts of the country stretched to capacity?

title: States Are Swimming in Cash Due to Booming Tax Revenue, Federal Aid
summary: New York, California, Florida are among the states planning big one-time investments in worker bonuses, tax rebates and paying down debt. Numerous states are proposing tax rebates and bonuses for public workers as the fiscal doldrums of early 2021 give way to fat times fueled by booming markets, growing incomes and federal aid.

title: Microsoft Gambles on Troubled Activision, But Risks Are Likely Manageable
summary: A trend toward greater due-diligence rigor means deep-pocketed Microsoft is unlikely to be surprised by what it finds at Activision. Microsoft Corp. in its planned purchase of Activision Blizzard Inc. will take on a company with a troubled reputation surrounding its workplace culture, but the risks stemming from those problems are far from insurmountable, deals experts said.

title: Investors See New Sparkle in Europe's Tech Scene
summary: Government acceleration programs show signs of paying off. Europe's tech scene has struggled to emerge from the shadows of giants in the U.S. and Asia, but friendly local policies and a global overflow of investment capital are now giving the region a gusher of cash.

title: Chinese Developer Country Garden Raises $501 Million
summary: Convertible-bond deal follows rebound in property stocks earlier this week. China's largest developer by contracted sales took advantage of a pickup in investor sentiment toward the property sector to sell convertible bonds, after deciding against pursuing a similar deal last week.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Belarusian Officials Charged With Aircraft Piracy in Diversion of Ryanair Flight
summary: U.S. prosecutors allege officials used fake bomb scare to divert plane, arrest dissident. The U.S. Justice Department charged four Belarusian government officials with aircraft piracy, alleging they conspired to fabricate a bomb threat to divert a Ryanair Holdings PLC passenger jet last year to arrest a dissident journalist.

title: Singapore Kicks Off New Era of SPACs in Asia
summary: Three Temasek-linked deals seek to raise a total of $386 million. Three SPACs are making their debuts in Singapore this month, as the blank-check company framework gets a reboot in Asia.

title: Biden Seeks to Reassure Ukraine, Vowing a Strong Response to Russia
summary: President says any Russian troop movement into Ukraine would be considered an invasion, clarifying earlier remarks about a 'minor incursion'. President Biden said Thursday that any Russian troop movement into Ukraine would be considered an invasion, seeking to clear up confusion over his position on a potential incursion as the administration gave approval for U.S.-made weapons to be transferred to Kyiv.

title: Peloton Warns of Layoffs, Changes to Production
summary: CEO John Foley says the company is reviewing costs after report of production halt sent its shares tumbling. Peloton Interactive Inc . 's chief executive officer said the company is reviewing the size of its workforce and resetting production levels as the company adapts to more seasonal demand for its exercise equipment.

title: Jan. 6 Committee Asks Ivanka Trump to Voluntarily Cooperate With Probe
summary: The panel has been investigating last year's riot at the Capitol. WASHINGTON-The House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol has asked former President Donald Trump's daughter Ivanka Trump to cooperate with the panel voluntarily.

title: Adele Postpones Las Vegas Residency Due to Covid-19 Cases on Her Team
summary: The British pop star's show at Caesars Palace was to begin on Friday. Adele is postponing her Las Vegas residency, just one day before it was set to begin, following a rash of Covid-19 cases among her team and other hurdles that stymied preparations for the highly-anticipated show.

title: U.S. Charges Another Suspect in Haitian President's Killing
summary: Haitian businessman faces federal charges he provided weapons, ammunition in fatal shooting of Jovenel Moïse. U.S. prosecutors in Miami have detained and charged a second suspect in connection with the July assassination of Haitian President Jovenel Moïse, highlighting progress by American investigators even as the six-month probe in Haiti remains stalled.

title: Supreme Court Permits Texas Abortion Ban to Continue
summary: Court denies abortion providers' request to allow challenge to proceed in federal court; Justice Sotomayor's dissent calls case 'disaster for the rule of law'. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court allowed Texas' six-week abortion ban to remain in effect indefinitely, issuing an order Thursday blocking litigation against the law while the state's highest court weighs a procedural question related to the measure's enforcement.

title: China Evergrande's International Bondholders Threaten Legal Action
summary: Developer allegedly withheld crucial info about its liabilities and failed to engage with offshore creditors, bondholders' advisers say. A group of China Evergrande Group 's international bondholders threatened to move forward with a legal enforcement plan that could potentially include liquidation of the company's assets, after being unable to engage substantively with the troubled property developer for months.

title: Netflix Shares Sink as Company Sees Subscriber Growth Slowing
summary: Video streamer cites growing competition and 'an ongoing Covid overhang' for its membership forecast. Netflix Inc. said it expects to add a much smaller number of subscribers this quarter than it did a year ago as it adjusts to growing competition and lasting disruptions from the coronavirus pandemic, sending the video streamer's shares down sharply.

title: Rare Coral Reef Found Off Coast of Tahiti
summary: Divers discover a 2-mile stretch of rose-petal-shaped corals said to be in pristine condition. Technological advancements that allow scuba divers to reach deeper waters helped a team of scientists find and study a rare and pristine coral reef off the coast of Tahiti.

title: Part of Former Frick Estate In New Jersey Sells for $27.5 Million
summary: The seller listed it unofficially for $68 million more than a decade ago. A massive granite mansion in Alpine, N.J., has sold for $27.5 million, more than a decade after it was first offered for $68 million.

title: Oath Keepers Cached Weapons for Jan. 6 Capitol Attack, Prosecutors Say
summary: Cartloads of arms and ammunition were at the ready at a Virginia hotel, according to an indictment against members of the far-right militia group. WASHINGTON-The right-wing Oath Keepers militia group was prepared to move a stash of firearms and equipment from a Virginia hotel to rioters on Jan. 6 last year, federal prosecutors said, painting the most detailed portrait yet of the planning the group's members allegedly undertook as they tried to stop the certification of Joe Biden's 2020 presidential election win.

title: Union Pacific Says Covid-19 Left Railroad Understaffed
summary: CEO Lance Fritz says company underestimated loss of manpower as Omicron variant spread. Union Pacific Corp. said it was caught off guard by the number of workers absent because of quarantines and getting their vaccines, which led to fewer on-time trips and other deteriorating operating performance in the fourth quarter.
